content.title: Blunt Cerebrovascular Injury (BCVI)
content.summary: Traumatic injury to the carotid or vertebral arteries from blunt mechanisms, associated with significant stroke risk if undiagnosed and untreated.

definitions.definition: Injury to the carotid or vertebral arteries from blunt trauma, including dissection, pseudoaneurysm, thrombosis, or transection.

Grading system for BCVI: Grade I (intimal irregularity <25% narrowing), Grade II (>25% narrowing, intimal flap, or intraluminal thrombus), Grade III (pseudoaneurysm), Grade IV (occlusion), Grade V (transection with extravasation).

key_concepts.explanation: Risk factors that warrant CTA screening: cervical spine fractures involving foramen transversarium, C1-C3, or subluxation; skull base fractures; diffuse axonal injury with GCS <6; Le Fort II/III fractures; cervical soft tissue injury (seatbelt sign, hanging); and unexplained neurological deficit.
Untreated BCVI carries a 25-50% stroke risk. Most strokes occur within 72 hours of injury, emphasizing the importance of early screening and treatment.

Antiplatelet or anticoagulation therapy reduces stroke risk by 50-60%. Treatment choice depends on bleeding risk from associated injuries. Aspirin 325mg daily is commonly used when anticoagulation is contraindicated.

evidence.citation: Burlew et al., Western Trauma Association Algorithm, 2012
evidence.finding: Systematic screening and antithrombotic treatment reduces stroke rate from 26% to 5%

evidence.citation: Biffl et al., Grading Scale Validation, 2009
evidence.finding: Higher Biffl grades correlate with increased stroke risk and need for intervention

clinical_pearls: BCVI is present in 1-3% of all blunt trauma patients but up to 30% of patients with specific high-risk injuries
CTA has replaced conventional angiography as the screening modality of choice
Vertebral artery injuries are more common than carotid injuries due to the protected course of the carotid
Grade I and II injuries often heal with antithrombotic therapy alone
Endovascular stenting is reserved for pseudoaneurysms at risk of rupture or emboli
learning_objectives: Identify clinical and injury patterns requiring BCVI screening
Apply the Biffl grading system to classify BCVI severity
Describe the natural history and stroke risk of untreated BCVI
Compare antithrombotic strategies for BCVI management

cross_domain_references.context: BCVI is a preventable cause of stroke in trauma patients
